A pleasant village Link: /ShowUserReviews-g672705-d6412741-r753061420-Abyaneh_Village-Natanz_Isfahan_Province.html

With the exception of the Harpak fire temple, which is built of stone, all of the buildings are built of reddish mud-dried bricks. We were invited into a house by 2 elderly ladies, and I was hoping to hear them speak Middle Persian, but they didn't. The village is nice to wander…

marvelous ancient village Link: /ShowUserReviews-g672705-d6412741-r739050921-Abyaneh_Village-Natanz_Isfahan_Province.html

Abyaneh is famous for its reddish hue clay containing iron oxide, that’s why some people called it the Red Village. The red houses of the village with its lattice windows and wooden balconies have been built on the ancient architectural style, similar to Masouleh. The roofs of…

Still worth a visit Link: /ShowUserReviews-g672705-d6412741-r734297973-Abyaneh_Village-Natanz_Isfahan_Province.html

I came here with a driver who also became my guide while in the village. It’s a nice half day tour from the city, but I do recommend bringing a guide. The village itself is beautiful and unique, but you will not get much out of your visit if no one is there to tell you the story…

Just brilliant! Abyaneh is a dynamic tourism destination, somewhere you shouldn't miss on you way to Isfahan. The cute old couples who are still living in this beautiful places makes you to fall in love with their hospitality.
